nodes.bodyText: rnn, because you don't support null values in equals method
these 3 variables are not used in this commit (row filter support)
do you have a test where row filter tries to access symbols that are within query, but shouldn't be visible row filter (because they are not table output symbols)?
No, but I'll add one that attempts to reference a column from the outer scope in a correlated subquery.
Do you have a test where row filters are applied to tables used within the table defined with WITH?
I'll add one
Can you please add a test where RowFilterScopeEntry#identity matters. Like there would be 2 level recursive row filter but each row filter would be applied for different identity.

There's already a test for that: testDifferentIdentity. It runs the query as "user", which results in a filter orderkey IN (SELECT orderkey FROM orders) being applied. That filter needs to be evaluated as user run-as-user, which then results in another filter being applied to the nested reference to orders: orderkey = 1
maybe extract the below block as method, so you don't have uninitialized variable.

I think that's overkill. It makes the code harder to follow, as you have to navigate multiple methods to understand what this is doing, and it doesn't really save much other than that variable declaration.
can you please add a test for this?
rnn
move this constructor down as last constructor
it would be nice to pass session here, so it would be obvious from reading the test which row filter is going to be applied

Indeed, but it requires some refactoring to how we build sessions and how the methods are invoked to make it reasonably clean. We can do that as a follow up. I don't want to extend the scope of this PR.

Consider a test case like:
     // subquery "sql-injection"
        assertRowFiltering(
                "WITH region(regionkey, name) AS (VALUES (0, 'ASIA'), (1, 'ASIA'), (2, 'ASIA'), (3, 'ASIA'), (4, 'ASIA'))" +
                        "SELECT name FROM nation ORDER BY name LIMIT 1",
                "SELECT 'CHINA'", // if sql-injection would work then query would return ALGERIA
                rowFilter("nation", "regionkey IN (SELECT regionkey FROM region WHERE name = 'ASIA')", getSession().getUser()));
That's a clever test. Thanks! I'll add it
As I understand it will use RowFilterKey from TestingAccessControlManager. It would be nice to have a test that would require using different keys in analysis based on identity.
Not sure I understand. This test does that -- it applies to different filters to two different instances of the orders table based on the identity being used to evaluate the tables.
Unfortunately, anything involving views would require a connector that supports them AND supports filters/masks. We don’t have any.

s/identity/user
here and everywhere else
No, because this is actually a SQL authorization identifier. Eventually, it will be either a user or a role, as expected by standard SQL authorization model.
So then I think you should use io.prestosql.spi.security.PrestoPrincipal
No, principal has way too much stuff. This is just an authorization identifier as described by the SQL spec.
s/identity/user

I don't think that connector should return catalog. Connector is only aware of catalog name it is using, don't know anything about other catalogs. Do we need ConnectorViewExpression and SystemViewExpression?

The catalog/schema/identity make up the "environment" under which the filter or mask should be evaluated. They are needed for the purpose of resolving relative table references, and it's exactly the same mechanism we use for views. In a way, row filters and masks behave like dynamic views.
if row filters and column masks are using same mechanism during semantic analysis, should we extract common code as some entity?

I don't think that saves us much and introduces unnecessary abstraction. We'd need a generic holder class parameterized on the scope entry type and the container (List<Expression> vs Map<String, List<Expression>). We also still have to have the register/unregister/hasXXX/getXXX methods, the logic to create the keys, etc., in Analysis.
rnn
Shouldn't getColumnMasks() return Multimap?
I wanted to be explicit about the ordering of the expressions, so a Map with a List seemed more appropriate.
Add a test where there are two column masks (one connector level and one system level) and where we could notice the order in which they were applied.

Unfortunately, we don't have infrastructure to do that. It would require implementing masking support in real connectors. The tests rely on simulating the ordering of the masks by explicitly registering them in TestingAccessControl
Then I think we need to write TestAccessControl unit tests where you could inject some fake system and connector access control to test (concrete) the order.
Do you have a suggestion about where to do it! I don’t believe we have anything where we can inject fake connectors like that and still be able to run reasonable queries.
Maybe we could add column mask support for file based access controls, then we could use both of them in single test.
That’s an option, but it increases the scope of this change (we need to design how we want to represent them in the files, etc)

Another option is to add a test to io.prestosql.security.TestAccessControlManager where you could inject your custom plugins, like: https://github.com/prestosql/presto/pull/2924/files#diff-969c42278114183bfc24a2cde29f7289R200
That kind of test is super brittle. But ok, added it.

Why ViewExpression contains identity? We are already passing identity to access control. It is like "give me a row filter for bob", and getting a response "here is a row filter FOR BOB" (instead of just "here is a row filter that you requested").

nodes.bodyText:
The identity attached to the filter is the identity that should be used to evaluate any tables referenced by the filter. If you ask: “give me a filter for table T for Bob”, you might get “here’s the filter, and any tables referenced in sub queries in that filter should be resolved as user Admin”. This can be useful to constrain permissions based on data contained in lookup tables only accessible to users with more privileges.
It’s no different than how views work.
